Title: A New Typology of Multilingual and Plurilingual Digital Lexicographical Resources: Bridging the Gap between Dictionaries and Platforms

Introduction:
In this paper, we propose a novel taxonomy of multilingual and plurilingual digital lexicographical resources, aiming to provide a clear distinction and implementation of quantitative and qualitative criteria. Our focus will be on lexicographical tools such as dictionaries, contrasting them with platforms and websites. Furthermore, we delve into the prototypical degree of multilingual and plurilingual resources.

Section 1: Multilingual and Plurilingual Digital Lexicographical Tools
This section introduces various multilingual and plurilingual digital lexicographical tools, including comprehensive dictionaries, bilingual dictionaries, monolingual dictionaries, and terminological databases. We examine their core features, functionalities, and advantages, highlighting their relevance in the digital age.

Section 2: Parameters and Typological Proposals
We propose several parameters to classify multilingual and plurilingual digital lexicographical resources based on their source language(s), target language(s), coverage, updates, and user interface. Furthermore, we present typological proposals for multilingual dictionaries and portals, emphasizing their role in the evolving landscape of lexicography.

Section 3: Multilingual and Plurilingual Resources: Prototypical Degree and Implications
This section discusses the prototypical degree of multilingual and plurilingual resources, shedding light on their varying degrees of comprehensiveness and accuracy. We also examine the implications of this prototypical degree on language learners, translators, and researchers.

Conclusion:
The conclusion summarizes the main findings of our paper, emphasizing the importance of a comprehensive and nuanced understanding of multilingual and plurilingual digital lexicographical resources. We also discuss the potential avenues for future research and the ongoing evolution of these resources in the digital era.

Additionally, we raise thought-provoking questions regarding the object of study in multilingual and plurilingual lexicography, encouraging further debate and collaboration among researchers and practitioners in the field.
